Award.AwardTitle: Asymptotic Problems for Stochastic Processes and Differential Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Several classes of asymptotic problems will be considered. The first class concerns metastability and stochastic resonance for multiscale systems. The general approach to metastability and stochastic resonance in the framework of large deviations was developed in our previous papers. In the case of multiscale systems these notions should be modified. In particular, new effects appear in systems which are close to Hamiltonian and in systems with a small delay. Another class consists of new problems for PDE's with a small parameter and related stochastic processes. To describe the limiting behavior in these classical problems one should consider equations on graphs or open book spaces related to the original problam. Reaction-Diffusion-Advection equations in incompressible fluids, in strongly unisotropic media, and in narrow tubes will be considered. The last class of problems concerns the averaging principle for systems with many degrees of freedom and multiwell Hamiltonians. It turns out that even in pure deteministic systems the slow motion can be, in a sense, stochastic.

Small perturbations of a system which often have negligible effects, when the system considered on a short time interval, can become crucial on larger timescale. The study of such effects is one of our main goals. We consider long time influence of small stochastic and deterministic perturbations and, under certain conditions, describe the long-time evolution of the system which essentially depends on the perturbations. Such kind of problems arise in numerous applications from physics and biology to economics and sociology. We are developing new mathematical approches to these problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When a mathematical model of a process in physics, engineering, biology, economics, or in another area is constructed one have to neglect many factors which can be considered as small, non-essential at least on relatively short time intervals. But in the long time, the neglected factors can become critical and can cause large deviations of the real process from the behavior suggested by the model. Therefore investigation of long time influence of small perturbations of a model is a very important problem.

               The neglected perturbations can be small in one or another sense. They can be deterministic or random. The main goal of this project is to develop a mathematical theory describing the long time influence of small deterministic or stochastic perturbations on the system under consideration. Roughly speaking, there are two ways how small perturbations can influence the system: First way, when we can separate the fast and the slow components in the process. The slow component plays the leading part in the long time behavior of the system. To characterize the slow component one should average the system with respect the fast component which can be approximated by the model without perturbations. This is so called averaging principle which is widely used in science. We developed a mathematical theory of averaging when the system has to go near an unstable state. This can result in a stochastic behavior of the slow motion even when the original system and perturbations are pure deterministic. If the system has several asymptotically stable regimes, random perturbations can lead to transitions from one stable regime to another. This is the second way of the long time evolution. These transitions are described by the large deviation theory for stochastic processes developed in our previous papers. In this case the transitions, in spite of the fact that they are caused by stochastic perturbations, have a strong deterministic component which often can be described in rather explicit form. We consider also the interplay between the averaging and large deviations.

              Perturbation theory is one of the most powerful methods of applied mathematics. Therefore education of yang researchers in this area is very important. I regularly teach graduate courses on asymptotic methods for stochastic processes and differential equations. I have many graduate students.Together with my colleague Alexander Wentzell, we wrote a book “Random Perturbations of Dynamical Systems”. An extended third edition of this book was published  in  2012.
